Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation2: A routine audit is scheduled far ahead, leaving ample time to update documentation
Story:
I stared at my phone, reading my younger brother’s text: “Hey, we’re all going to the lake this weekend. You in?” I could almost hear his hopeful tone, remembering how I’d promised to be more present, to include him in my life the way he always tried to include me. I wanted to say yes, to show him that he mattered, that I respected our bond enough to make time for him.

But as I glanced at my laptop, the audit checklist glared back at me. The routine safety audit was still weeks away, but I knew the documentation needed careful updates. My team relied on me to ensure everything was perfect—no shortcuts, no missed details. If I let things slide now, it could mean trouble later, not just for me, but for everyone on the project.

I felt the pressure mounting from both sides. My brother’s expectation for connection and inclusion clashed with my responsibility to my team and the standards I was sworn to uphold. My thumb hovered over the keyboard, torn between two worlds, each demanding a different version of me.
